utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Apparently. But you know what I'm offended by? I'm offended by, well, I'm offended by people he do vanity plates at all.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: Do you remember this. In "Seinfeld" they had a similar episode about this, in fact with the same Assman reference. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Assman? These don't belong to me. I'm not the Assman. I think there's been a mistake.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What's your name again?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Cosmo Kramer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Cosmo Kramer. You are the Assman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not the Assman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Well, as far as the state of New York is concerned, you are.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: Apparently in Saskatchewan, a real Assman cannot put his name out there. I say be a proud Assman, put your name on your license. He should take it to the high court.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Media-ite.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Raymond --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: -- for that Friday Follies. My God, what's happened to us? After a batch of stolen texts revealed the sultry affair he was having, Amazon and "Washington Post" CEO Jeff Bezos is leveling a charge of extortion against the "National Enquirer." So why is Peter Schweizer calling him a hypocrite? That's next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: A lurid affair caught on text and charges of extortion, and that's the state of play between one of the wealthiest men on the planet and the most famous tabloid in American history. Trace Gallagher has the story tonight from our west coast newsroom that's buzzing. Trace?

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Hi, Laura. When the world's richest man says he was blackmailed by the world's most famous tabloid it tends to generate a little buzz, and now you have the feds involved. First Bezos went on a blogging platform called Medium and posted details of the alleged extortion, including messages sent to him from the "National Enquirer," its parent company American Media, and American Media CEO David Pecker, threatening to release intimate photos of Bezos and his girlfriend Lauren Sanchez unless Bezos agreed to, one, call off his investigation of how "The Enquirer" got the private pictures and texts, and, two, issued a statement saying the investigation that uncovered his affair with Sanchez was not politically motivated. Bezos of course refused, writing, quote, "Of course I don't want personal photos published, but I also won't participate in their well-known practice of blackmail, political favors, political attacks, and corruption. I prefer to stand up, roll this log over, and see what crawls out." American Media has now responded, saying it wasn't blackmailing Bezos and that the messages were good faith negotiations to resolve the matter, saying, quote, "American Media believes fervently that it acted lawfully in the reporting of the story of Mr. Bezos." That said, American Media CEO David Pecker says the company will conduct its own investigation into what, if any, action needs to be taken. And the government is also getting in on the action. Federal prosecutors are now looking into the "National Enquirer's" is handling of the Bezos extramarital affair story. As for how the intimate photos were leaked in the first place, a reporter for the "Washington Post" owned by Jeff Bezos says that he has spoken with Bezos' lead security consultant Gavin de Becker. Watch. MANUEL ROIG-FRANZIA, "WASHINGTON POST": Gavin de Becker told us that he does not believe that Jeff Bezos' phone was hacked. He thinks it's possible that a government entity might have gotten hold of his text messages.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Though earlier, Gavin de Becker said publicly he thought the brother of Bezos' mistress Lauren Sanchez played a role in leaking those private photos and texts. We shall see. Laura?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Trace, great job. And our next guest finds the invasion of privacy complaints from Bezos warranted, but also hypocritical. Filmmaker Peter Schweizer has a new documentary that examines how these tech behemoths operate in stolen and manipulated information, that is your information, by the way. Peter joins us now. Peter, the "National Enquirer" seems to be in the wrong here with how they came after Bezos, but it's kind of ironic, isn't it, that Bezos is crying foul about stolen text when these tech companies can be guilty in the end of much worse.

utterances.speaker: PETER SCHWEIZER, PRESIDENT, GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY INSTITUTE
utterances.sentences: That is exactly right, Laura. About a decade ago, Eric Schmidt of Google declared that privacy was dead, and the tech titans have essentially been selling everybody's information. And what's troubling is they don't just use that information, our information, to sell us advertising and sorts of things like that. They also use it against us. And so to me it's quite ironic. I sympathize with Jeff Bezos, but I find it quite ironic that they're raising privacy concerns when the high-tech industry, primarily Google and Facebook, but also Amazon pedal in selling our information and invading our privacy on a regular basis.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Peter, another point is that the employees of the "Washington Post" who ultimately work for Bezos saw that one blog post basically trying to out the "National Enquirer" and are just celebrating him as a national hero. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There is a certain amount of badass-ness about Jeff Bezos that I think makes us all proud to work for him.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: "Badass-ness," that's where we are. I want to play one more thing, though, because this is funny. This is Dylan Byers of NBC also saying that this all could be good in a way for Bezos. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: DYLAN BYERS, MSNBC MEDIA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: To me it's not so much what does "National Enquirer" have on Jeff Bezos that's driving this story. What I wonder is what does Jeff Bezos be have on the "National Enquirer"? What does he have about the ties to Trump? He has earned his journalism wings with this move. So he has pulled off a masterstroke in terms of recasting his own image, in terms of making himself look like a good guy again.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: That's an pretty interesting term. A good guy, a hero, he's a guy just like you and me, Donny Deutsch said on "Morning Joe." So it is kind of an image recast. But then again, Pecker, he has already gotten an immunity deal from Mueller, so it's like he's working with Mueller on some of this killing the stories about Trump deal. So I don't get where any of these people are going. What do you have to hid? What does AMI have to hide? I don't get it.

utterances.speaker: SCHWEIZER
utterances.sentences: It's interesting, Jeff Bezos is in this story kind of the victim, right, so that is going to help him. But I think most people are going to look at these tech titans and ultimately not view them in a sympathetic light. And it's not, in my book, because they make a lot of money. More power to them. They create these great companies, these great products and services. But it's because of the invasion of privacy. With all of these online companies including Amazon, a big part of their revenue stream is selling information about you. And they use that information against you. Some of them at Google and others talk about the fact that their goal is not just to sell your information. It's to actually change and manipulate your values and your views. So I sympathize with Jeff Bezos in this case, but to paint him as some kind of a victim like the rest of us I think is patently ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Peter, before we go, I've got to get you quick, quick thoughts on Hillary Clinton, who I guess is, maybe they just need a woman to get the job done over there running for president. She is still dangling out the prospect of running. And it looked a little more likely today that she was actually going to throw her hat in the ring. With everything that you exposed about Hillary and the email server, how good would that be?

utterances.speaker: SCHWEIZER
utterances.sentences: I think it would be an enormous gift to President Trump if Hillary Clinton were to run. What I'm betting on is that Terry McAuliffe, the former governor of Virginia, will be the stalking horse for the Clinton machine. They're longtime associates. He raised a lot of money for them when Bill was president, they helped him get elected governor of Virginia. So they're going to try to live vicariously through Terry McAuliffe and go up against the Obama machine in 2020 with their candidate. I think it's going to be quite a slugfest.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Wow, Peter, thanks so much. We really appreciate it tonight. And we have highlighted a number of inventive funding ideas to help build that wall over the last several months. Up next is a Tennessee lawmaker who says that he has figured it out. He is here next to tell us how.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Tennessee Representative Bruce Griffey, filed legislation earlier this week that would establish a fee imposed on customers for transmitting money through certain entities. That's a mouthful. Basically, what this does is require a levy on money transfers from Tennessee to Mexico, and then set aside those fees collected for the border wall. His state would be not the only one to explore such a measure. Arizona, Montana, and West Virginia are considering or have considered similar proposals. Here now is Bruce Griffey. Could they actually get the job done if a number of the state legislatures banded together?

utterances.speaker: REP. BRUCE GRIFFEY, R-TN, TENNESSEE STATE REPRESENTATIVE
utterances.sentences: Certainly, if we have enough state legislatures that would all act together and get on the stick and let's get something done. I'm so frustrated that some of our Republican representatives are not fully supporting President Trump as I feel they should, and propose this legislation.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Name some names, Congressman. I don't want to do pie in the sky stuff, to quote Michael Bloomberg, because I'm telling you, Mike Rogers in Alabama recommended the same thing. He pushed this bill back in the summer of 2017. It was focus on Honduras. Honduran immigrants in the United States send back $4.33 billion just in the year of 2016 to 2017, $4.33 billion. So that, you tax it over two percent over 10 years, there's your wall, bingo, $20 billion. So he pushed this back then, didn't get any traction. I think it's a no-brainer. This is a complete no-brainer.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFEY
utterances.sentences: I agree. I don't know why it hasn't been done more fully, and I just felt like I'm a freshman legislator in the state of Tennessee. I wanted to do my part to support the president and the efforts to build a secure border wall.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: When we look at the, I think what you see on social media, a little off this topic, the concern now about these blackface controversies and racism and what people did in their past, and pictures, and language, I feel like there is a new focus on the south in general. Online I see entire streams of messages about how certain states should basically not be part of the United States anymore. Tennessee isn't one of them, but it's like Alabama, Florida, now Virginia, maybe even Mississippi, they are so filled with a bunch of white southern racist that they can't be redeemed. I kid you not, that is where the conversation has gone online.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFEY
utterances.sentences: I understand. It's unfortunate. But one of the bright spots of this may be is for this conversation to come out and show that a lot of these Democratic congressmen and governors, and they are so hypocritical. And it's frustrating. The old Democratic Party that I used to know about is not this current Democratic Party. And I certainly wish we could get back to get some serious discussions and Democrats and Republicans come together, and let's work through the problems and come up with the best solutions for Americans.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much for joining us. An interesting idea for trying to build the border wall. We'll take all of them we can get. My final thoughts on a busy week, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right, guys, if you haven't downloaded my podcast, shame on you, because you missed RBG out on the town this week. Arroyo and I unpacked it all. Subscribing is easy. Go to Podcastone.com, or to iTunes, and you'll love it. And Mike Emanuel and the "Fox News @ Night" team now take it from here. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. utterances.speaker: LAURA INGRAHAM, HOST
utterances.utterance: This is “The Ingraham Angle” from Washington tonight with a Fox News Alert, and a big one, Virginia Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax is under increasing pressure to resign tonight. This, after a second accuser, has called him out for sexual misconduct. This time the allegation is a forcible rape 19 years ago. 2020 Presidential aspirants in the Democrat field have been quick tonight to call for Fairfax's resignation. And while it's tempting to delight, in the downfall of a Democrat who peddles in double standards, I believe Fairfax deserves a full examination of the facts before he's convicted by his fellow Democrats or frankly by the public. But, for the latest, including some moves toward impeachment hearings. Wow! We now go to Ellison Barber, live tonight in Richmond. Ellison.

utterances.speaker: ELLISON BARBER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Hi, Laura. Yes, a Virginia State Delegate says if the Lieutenant Governor does not step down by Monday he plans to introduce articles of impeachment. That Delegate just wrapped up a press conference. Here's some what he had to say.

utterances.speaker: PATRICK HOPE, D-VA, HOUSE OF DELEGATES MEMBER
utterances.utterance: There's no question that violent sexual assault clearly qualifies as a high crime. The House of Delegates will have to grant me unanimous consent. I would hope that no member would stand in the way of this process getting underway.

utterances.speaker: HOPE
utterances.utterance: The Lieutenant Governor has not been charged or convicted of anything. He denies any wrongdoing. He is facing sexual assault allegations from two different women. One says he forced her to perform oral sex on him in a hotel room during the 2004 DNC convention. Another says, he raped her in 2000 when they were both students at Duke University. In a same, Lieutenant Governor said, "I deny this latest unsubstantiated allegation. It is demonstrably false. I have never forced myself on anyone ever. I demand a full investigation into these unsubstantiated and false allegations". Lieutenant Governor then went on to say that he had passed two FBI background checks in his past and these allegations did not come up. He says, that this is a coordinated smear campaign effort and that he will not resign. The law firm representing the second, most recent accuser, says "Mr. Fairfax's attack was premeditated and aggressive" and that "Ms. Watson shared her account of the rape with friends in a series of e-mails and Facebook messages that are now in our possession. Additionally, we have statements from former classmates corroborating that Ms. Watson immediately told friends that Mr. Fairfax had raped her." Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Ellison great reporting tonight. Thanks so much. And we're going to talk about all this - the Former DNC Chair Donna Brazile and a lot of other topics in a matter of moments. But, first, we want to get some perspective from Virginia tonight and for that we go to Tim Hannigan who's the Chairman of the Fairfax County, Republican Party. Now Tim we still don't have any hard evidence that Fairfax indeed commit these horrific acts - both sexual assaults. Yet the Democrats are jumping all over each other to call for his resignation tonight. Now how do the State GOP leaders feel about this, especially given what we saw with all the jumping all over Kavanaugh when those allegations came up. And do Democrats see any irony in all of this?

utterances.speaker: TIM HANNIGAN, FAIRFAX COUNTY, VA GOP CMTE CHAIR
utterances.utterance: Well, I can't speak for the Democrats. But I dare say that many of the many Republicans believe in exactly what you just said now, which is, that these are serious allegations that require serious attention and due process. But I think there's an angle here that maybe is being overlooked. And that angle is that the start of this whole unraveling of our state government, which has so embarrassed Virginians, was a Bill that was proposed by a Delegate from Fairfax County where I'm from, which called for third trimester abortion, and what was really infanticide. And then Governor Northam--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's been kind of swept under the rug.

utterances.speaker: HANNIGAN
utterances.utterance: Right

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: While everyone is focusing on these decades-old issues of blackface or sexual assault, as important as those are to many Americans. That is interesting, because without the revelation of what the heck is happening in Virginia among the democrats with this late term abortion, infanticide, none of this other stuff probably would have come to light, at least not now, at least not in the way it has one after the other. But I have to ask you Tim, I'm watching the comments - I'm going to bring this up with Donna later - Donna Brazile. But I'm looking at some of these comments online. Every time there's an article about blackface or this person dressed up - online people are saying Virginia is a racist State. Virginia still believes in the confederacy, all going after Virginia, Alabama, Florida one of the-- The hatred being cast at the entire Commonwealth of Virginia, which I'm a proud resident, is really disheartening to a lot of us. And it's uncalled for.

utterances.speaker: HANNIGAN
utterances.utterance: Right, it is uncalled for.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's bad acts from some people. It's uncalled for.

utterances.speaker: HANNIGAN
utterances.utterance: And it doesn't reflect reality. I've lived in Virginia now for 27 years and that's not the way Virginians are. And Virginians feel let down by these Democrats in positions of governing right now. But the reason why I had mentioned that infanticide is because it demonstrates how far the Democrats have moved away from the mainstream.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes. Tim, I'm going to cut you off. But - we got to go. But I think, look, everybody has to take a breath here. Don't convict people until some type of due process or evidence is actually in. We really appreciate it. When we come back special "Awards for The Hearing Impaired Democrats". Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee embarrassed themselves today. Now having languished in the minority since 2011, they have been itching to sink their teeth into anything and any one Trump related. Now forget the important oversight function of the Committee. There were too many political points to be scored. There were too many Congressional reputations to burnish, too many opponents to burn. And despite the fact that he's only going to be in his job for maybe another week or so, Acting Attorney General Matt Whitaker was in the hot seat. Recall, that he only stepped into this role three months ago when Attorney General Sessions was fired. But every, Democrat without exception, grandstanded. For the most part they asked questions that had nothing to do - zero relevance to their proper oversight role. So the only purpose was to hit him with cheap shot after cheap shot after cheap shot, knowing that Whitaker was rightly going to assert what's called the "Deliberative Process Privilege" in refusing to answer questions about conversations he had with other DOJ staff or with the President himself. It's totally expected. So given the Democrats over-the-top performances today, and it being the awards season after all, we thought tonight would give out our own awards. So for "Most Frustrated Inquisitor", the award goes to, Representative Mary Gay Scanlon.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEW WHITAKER, ACTING UNITED STATES ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: Congresswoman--

utterances.speaker: REP. MARY GAY SCANLON, D-PENN.
utterances.utterance: isn't it correct that the ruling--

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: --I'm not going discuss an ongoing litigation. Congresswoman, I don't disagree that a District Court Judge--

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.utterance: Mr. Whitaker, you may be confused here.

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: --in litigation on this issue across the country.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.utterance: Did Attorney General Sessions asked--

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: This is the subject of ongoing litigation.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.utterance: OK. So we'll then the record reflects that again you're refusing to answer the question.

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: In example where--

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.utterance: It's a "Yes" or "No" question.

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: --during the first term of the Obama administration, they filed, I believe, one--

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.utterance: OK, reclaiming my time. No running out the clock--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Nice Job. And for Best to Repeater of a Question Unanswered, the award goes to - Democrat Congresswoman Sylvia Garcia.

utterances.speaker: REP. SYLVIA GARCIA, D-TX
utterances.utterance: How many children are still separate from their families as we sit here today?

utterances.speaker: MATTHEW WHITAKER, ACTING ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: That's a number that only DHS and HHS would know.

utterances.speaker: GARCIA
utterances.utterance: So you have no idea how many children--

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: Again, those are different departments.

utterances.speaker: GARCIA
utterances.utterance: How many children have been torn away from the arms of their mothers?

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: No, I would have to refer you to HHS and DHS again--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Now, I guess, she didn't know that the DOJ does not deal with the children after they are apprehended at the border? Now for "Speed Reading of an Overly Long Question", the award goes to Democrat Representative Joe Neguse.

utterances.speaker: REP. JOE NEGUSE, D-COLO.
utterances.utterance: I want to talk about another policy matter with respect to cannabis - and do you know if the Department of Justice and the DEA intend to support legitimate cannabis research that could help protect the health and safety of our citizens?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. We had to speed it up otherwise it would last till the end of the show, so bear with us. All right, special award for the "Stretch of the Day" goes to Democrat Congresswoman Debbie Mucarsel-Powell who asked Whitaker about his pre government service, his work he did at a 501(c)(3).

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: I haven't worked for fact in 16 months and I - in my preparation--

utterances.speaker: DEBBIE MUCARSEL-POWELL, D-FLA.
utterances.utterance: OK. Thank you, Mr. Whitaker.

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: I didn't review the filings--

utterances.speaker: MUCARSEL-POWELL
utterances.utterance: So where there only - thank you Mr. Whitaker, thank you. Where there only three board members in this 501(c)(3)?

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MUCARSEL-POWELL
utterances.utterance: I have some other questions here. All this time I'm waiting and I can't find the questions. This pertains to also an issue that's very close and dear to my heart - LGBTQ issues--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, no, no this is good. OK. For a "Revelation of a Radical Idea" - I mean a radical idea that no one had ever like - that where they're really going. The award goes to Democrat Congresswoman, Veronica Escobar.

utterances.speaker: VERONICA ESCOBAR, D-TX
utterances.utterance: I represent El Paso, Texas. Unfortunately, my community has been ground zero for many of this administration's cruel anti-immigrant, anti-American policies. Will the Department of Justice ensure that asylum seekers have access to Counsel in Mexico in order to allow them to prepare for their hearings, "Yes" or "No"?

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: We're going to continue to follow the policies of - at EOR that are currently in place.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. Wait a second. She thinks that we're supposed to now give the illegal aliens lawyers in other countries - anything else? All right, let's keep it going. "For Honorable mention (Of Time) - well, just in the nick of it, the award goes to Attorney General Acting Matthew Whitaker.

utterances.speaker: REP. JERROLD NADLER, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: Have you ever been asked to approve any request or action to be taken by the special counsel?

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: Mr. Chairman, I see that your five minutes is up and so - I--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I loved it. OK. And this is one of my personal favorites. The winner in the category of Least Time Spent Reading Witnesses' Bios goes to, Democrat Congressman Hakeem Jeffries.

utterances.speaker: REP. HAKEEM JEFFRIES, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: We're all trying to figure out who are you? Where did you come from and how the heck did you become the Head of the Department of Justice?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He was named by the President. OK. Well, then there was the always energetic Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee who wins the award for best bullying of a former college football player.

utterances.speaker: REP. SHEILA JACKSON LEE, D-TX
utterances.utterance: And you have not yet appeared for an Oversight Hearing, "Yes" or "No" - "Yes" or "No"?

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: The member has only five minutes. And if she--

utterances.speaker: REP. DOUG COLLINS, R-GA
utterances.utterance: If we just discover that - I mean, "Yes" or "No"--

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: --she wants a "Yes" or "No" answer; she's entitled to it. I will not allow the witness to stall and waste the member's time.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.utterance: Can the clock be restored?

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: It was.

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry what was your - I don't know if your time's been restored or not.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.utterance: Mr. Attorney General, we're not joking here, and your humor is not acceptable.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I hope no one ever tells me that my humor is not acceptable. I'm waiting for that. All right, in the category of "Best Use of Props" in lieu of an actual question, it goes to (match) Congressman Ted Lieu.

utterances.speaker: REP. TED LIEU, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: There is no sentence in the constitution that says "The Sitting President of the United States cannot be indicted", correct?

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: Congressman--

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.utterance: Say, "Yes" or "No".

utterances.speaker: WHITAKER
utterances.utterance: As you know, I would--

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.utterance: I have it for you right here, because that sentence in this constitution is not, correct? I'm not trying to trick you. Is that sentence in this constitution? Mr. Chair, I'm just going to submit the U.S. Constitution for the record and say, no, that sentence is not in there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. All right. And for "Complete Lunacy" in a recurring series, we have a tie my friends. This has never happened and the "Ingraham Awards" before. The award goes to Representatives Eric Swalwell and Jerry Nadler.

utterances.speaker: REP. ERIC SWALWELL, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: Did you watchdog organization ever received contributions from foreign donors?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: Mr. Chairman Point of Order.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.utterance: I'd ask to stop the clock.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: --gentlemen will suspend. The gentleman will state this point of order.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: This is outside the scope of this hearing.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: No, no, no,

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.utterance: --if you want to sit down there with his lawyers, you can go sit down there, but you're not his lawyer

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: Gentleman will suspend.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: And neither you--

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.utterance: --You could sit down there, there's room.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.utterance: Both gentlemen will suspend.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. We're going to suspend too. I'm sure that that won't last - be the last award we ever give out this season. It's almost too many things happening. Now with the Democrats starting all manner of Trump investigations, you can rest assured there'll be lots of dramatic and absurd performances, twists and turns in the days ahead, and that's "The Angle". Still ahead, I go one-on-one with Former DNC Chair, Donna Brazile. She here to respond to what's going on in Virginia tonight, plus the increasing creep of PC puritanism that I discussed in last night's angle, so stay right there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bowing to the every demand of the politically correct puritans puts us on a dangerous path, slippery slope, whatever you want to call it. The concern is that without some safe space to make mistakes in the past, good people won't want to be involved in public life at all. Maybe, it's time to reconsider the shifting standards of the PC puritans. So last night I warned about how people in both parties, now even corporations are falling victim to the ever-shifting PC goalposts. Now, I worry that the real offenses like the donning of blackface, discriminatory intent as adults, well, that's being casually lumped in with imagined offenses like the release of an all-white tennis shoe being labeled insensitive during Black History Month. And could the attention given to these flash points have irreversible effects in our society and then just end up driving us all further apart when we need to come together for some real solutions. Now for some answers, we're joined by my friend of too many years to count, Donna Brazile, Former Chair of the Democratic National Committee and Co- Author of the Book "For Colored Girls Who Considered Politics". Donna Brazile, great to have you in tonight, thank you so much for joining us.

utterances.speaker: DONNA BRAZILE, FORMER DNC CHAIR
utterances.utterance: And I'm with you, during Black History Month you are wearing all black.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, and yesterday it was Green New Deal, I was wearing green. So I'm in complete thematic dress.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: We love it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. Thank you. All right, Donna, what do you make of all of all of this with - the problem in Virginia, but then we have the corporations saying white shoes are racist.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: I remember a couple of years ago when we say selling white sheets during Black History Month was also racist. Look, this is not about symbolism only. This is the substance of the conversation that perhaps we need to have as Americans. It's been almost 400 years now since the first group of Africans arrived at on the shores of Virginia. 400 years is a long time to have a conversation worthy of a great nation like ours. And I think, we often put aside you the moment and just deal with the controversy. And say, why won't - this is a great moment, for you and I to talk about race. Where are we in the 21st Century? Can we at least agree on the language that we must use in order to address some of these big issues, whether it is white males appearing in blackface, which clearly is objectionable, no matter the period, because we all know what it symbolizes. Or you know talking about white tennis shoes during a time when it's time to celebrate Black History Month. What are we going to celebrate during the month that we look at senior citizens, are we going to --?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No grey sneakers allowed?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Well, hell, I better dye my hair now. Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But you know what, when you think about this, you've got Ralph Northam the governor of Virginia, Democrat Governor, who gets up there and he talks about this photo. And doesn't really say it's - he's in one of the pictures. But then he comes up the next day and says I wasn't in either picture. He gets himself in trouble kind of two times. Once for the photo with the KKK guy, is the Colin Wayne (ph), I guess. Then saying it's not - it's neither person is myself. Then you move on to Justin Fairfax. We have more allegations about him today, which I'll get to. Then you get the next in line, also said, Well, I've dressed up as a rapper.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: OK. And then we got the Majority Leader, who's a Republican. See, it's not it's not a partisan issue.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think it is actually. Some Republicans are trying to make it partisan. I actually think Democrats jump on Republicans--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: And Republicans jump on them.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --on something they did 30 years ago and now Republicans think I'm going to get you back, because you have a double standard. And my point is, is there - and you talk about this. Is there any safe space where we can have this conversation? I know you as a person. You know me as a person. We've known each other for a long time. We don't agree on a lot of stuff.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But you can have a reasonable conversation as adults. I think the rest of the country watching this show all over the place, they're saying, "I get along with people".

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Like, what is this that's happening? So where do we go we go from here for that amnesty or that safe space?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Well, I love to use the word amnesty, because I do believe there's a path to redemption. I'll give you a good example. Back in the 1990s, I was - that was a Congressional staffer. Robert Byrd, the former leader in the United States Senate and a former Klansmen.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wasn't he grand wizard, wasn't he in the Klan?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: And a recruiter, he was all of the above. Robert Byrd went to the floor of the United States Senate and denounced his engagement with the Klan, his involvement with the Klan. I thought that was a moment that we should have this conversation. And yet, John Lewis and many others went and say, "thank you". "Thank you for not only denouncing that that racist".

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But that wouldn't be good enough today, Donna, that would not be good enough today.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Well, that's a start. That's the start. Acknowledged the past. We cannot--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But he was actually an acting member of the KKK and you still got the Robert Byrd rest stop or Robert Byrd Library, the Robert Byrd - everything in West Virginia.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And so today given the new standard people got to resign immediately. They got to get out of public life. You'd have to rip down all those Robert Byrd things, whether he apologized or not, we had Ralph Northam apologize.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: But not only did he apologize, but he went on to not only spearhead legislation like the renewal of The Voting Rights Act. He went - he endorsed Barack Obama in 2008--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, but doesn't matter. Today, none of that matters, because there is no redemption for anybody today.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: That's it. What I'm saying is that there is a path forward. We--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So if you're only a liberal you can get redeemed?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not saying liberal. I mean, if Robert Byrd was a Republican, if Robert Byrd was a whatever - independent. The point is, is that there we should have an individual path. Look, there are many times in my life - look at this - this is I got a good rocking chair.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tippy-Tippy.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Look they're many - no, this is too early for me. There are many times--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's late.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Look, there are many - there were several moments in my life when I've had to say, "You know, what, I was wrong.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: And I've apologized for it. And you know what? It made me a better human being, because I had to lower, I had to humble myself and that's--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, I do that every Donna.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: I do it too.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. There's a lot of concern over the Democratic Party right now in Virginia. I'm a Virginia resident. Love this. Went to University of Virginia. But as promised (ph), it's not just moving Left, it's moving more towards Socialism. And in this piece titled from the National Journal, "Democrats are boosting trump's reelection prospects". One liberal Democratic strategist was alarmed by the rising tide of socialism within the Democrat Party, it said this. "We're on an out-of- control roller coaster going 100 miles-an-hour, and we have no functioning brake. One is leading and the void could not be more clear". So do you share that concern?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: We have raised the profile of one dynamic young woman just elected to Congress, who I do believe is a mover and shaker.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: AOC.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: AOC. And what I like about her is that people are talking about these issues now. We're talking about Green Deal. We're talking about raising the wage. We're talking about issues that Democrats have been talking about the years, but all of a sudden--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Right. But the Democrats are signing on to something that's not even a prescription, it's just this resolution that would eliminate cars, eliminate planes--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And give people jobs who are unwilling or unable to work - unwilling to work would also get a minimum of living. Is that the Democrat Party today?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: No, because we have we have several proposals. I told someone the other day, we have like six different proposals on how to strengthen our health care system.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And Pelosi doesn't like this.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: But you know my mother said it best, when we were growing up. She said, "It's not what they call, it is what you answer to". I think most Democrats would answer to--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They know--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: --How are you? We are Americans who believe in giving every - each and every American healthy start is term life. I mean that's not socialist.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But that's not what - all said - I don't want to say it's all about AOC. But there is genuine concern within the Democrat Party that you think you have Trump on the ropes, but then all of a sudden, whoa, it's whiplash to the left--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Oh my God--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --when the country said, wait a second, wait a second, wait a second.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Laura--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, I got to ask you about Northam. Do you think Northam should go?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: He is not going.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He said wasn't going to go today. But do you think he should?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: The Democratic Party of Virginia has said, we're going to spend this weekend talking to our officials and figure out a path forward.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So you don't have a feeling on whether he should go or not?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: I don't believe we know the answer, because as you know on Friday night, he said one thing and then on Saturday night - you may have to wait till tomorrow afternoon.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I had someone on my show on Friday--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Well, you need to show on Saturday--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I had someone on Friday, Jo diGenova said he's a racist and I love Joe and I said, "I don't think he is a racist".

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: No he is not.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But I'm getting heat as A Republican for standing up for Democrats. It would be nice if the favor were returned when conservatives are unfairly attacked, there's like three people - like, I can count on one hand to defend me--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Ronald Regan launched his campaign in the Neshoba County, Mississippi.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Right, me bet.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: And a few after his election he signed the bill to make Martin Luther King a National Holiday. We need a have to redemption - every American, regardless of color.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: About this Fairfax, these allegations against him?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: I am--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --the Lieutenant Governor.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: I am deeply alarmed at these allegations and--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And a second woman came forward today.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: I am deeply alarmed. I have talked to Justin.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He denies it.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Justin is someone I know very well.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, he denies it. He is denying this. He said, it didn't happen, and she said she has told people and contemporaries. And then we don't know much more.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: We've run this story before. But you know what? You need to have an opportunity to hear more, to have the due process, and investigation. But I support these women coming forward.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, Donna Brazile. It's so much fun. I haven't talked to you--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: We might be doing Women's History Month now--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: And then the age, so I can dye my hair.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All the month, I can only invite Donna during--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Senior citizens comes on.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --during actual thematic months.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Senior citizens.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: There must be a hot chick diva month and I want to also come in that month.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, Raymond said that Donna is the only person who doesn't age over like two decades. Has no age. Thanks so much for coming on. We really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: Go Saints.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Oh God, they're still talking about the Saints, these people. All right coming up, what if your last name also doubles as an offensive term? Should you be able to put it on your license plate anyway? Plus, when do the friendly skies become too friendly? Huh - talking spittle and other things on those blankets, with Raymond Arroyo, "Friday Follies" next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's Friday, and that means it's time for Friday Follies. A Canadian man has denied putting his name on a license plate, Delta and Coke are walking buck what some are calling a creepy marketing campaign. Joining us now with all the details, blanketing us blanketing us with wisdom, Raymond Arroyo, FOX News contributor, and of course "New York Times" bestselling author of the upcoming book "Will Wilder and The Amulet of Power." My kids just got their copy, Raymond. Raymond, let's start with this controversy over a napkin and what Delta thought was a good idea.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: The napkin came as they often do with the complementary beverage. But it read in very small print, "Be a little old school. Write down your number and give it to your plane crash. You never know." There was a space to write your phone number. Some were outraged by this. People tweeted they thought it was creepy. One woman said she felt stigmatized and pressured. Eventually Delta and Coke apologize. Does this offend you at all?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Not at all.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I don't mind this. But people were upset.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: First of all, what is the big deal? You are close to other people on a plane anyway. You might as well if there's someone interesting to you.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Some of the people tweeting said it made them feel uncomfortable because you're encouraging ogling. But my feeling is --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Here's an idea, if you don't want somebody to ogle, I always say oogle (ph). Is it ogle?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It's ogle.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Why do I say oogle (ph)? Ogle you, then don't come in with short shorts with your entire pubic area showing for the whole plane to see hanging out of your clothes, and maybe we won't be.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Ogling you. I would've liked this to be a conversation starter, like name your favorite book, and then you leave it in place for the person to put their favorite book or favorite TV show. Conversation is good, and a little romance in the air, I don't mind that. But not for me, anyway. The only romance am having is if my wife is in the aisle.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I have met some interesting people.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Oh, you have?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Anything you'd like to talk about?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Not right now, but yes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Strangers on a plane.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Better to get a date than to keep you warm with those airplane blankets. In turns out according to travel and leisure -- did you love that transition?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, great.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: They only provide clean blankets on originating flights. All the other blankets are just refolded.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Disgusting.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And by the way, don't like the cellophane baggie fool you. You think oh, this is clean. A flight attendant blogger Sara Keagle, says they just repackage them with everybody's germs.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Hello?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Now, Laura I have to share this with you. There was a tweet that emerged, a comedian, Nicole Byer went on a Delta flight. When she unfurled her blanket, she claims she found this goodie in it. Human feces. I don't even know what to say.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That must be diapering the baby.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: They do sometimes diaper them on the pulldown tray.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She didn't have a wipe. She ran out of wipes. And let me just tell you, never put your hands and the seatback compartment. I put my hand in there once, went right into a dirty diaper. That thing is nasty.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Raymond and I travel, we travel with the staff a lot, and we bring wipes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Lysol wipes. Lysol wipes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: People are looking at us, can you wipe my seat too. I'm happy to do so.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: What do I look like, Hazel?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Talk about dated references. But I often do help other people clean their seats.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: "Wall Street Journal" claim blankets are only cleaned every five to 30 days.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The drool.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: So avoid the blankets. Just don't touch anything. Wear your hazmat.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Come in with a hazmat. That is a lovely transition to the next story. Dave Assman of Saskatchewan in Canada attempted to put his name on a license plate. What happened?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The Assmans, that's the way your pronouce it, Oss-man. Some crude people might say Ass-man, had quite as storied history. Dave's distant relatives Dick appeared on the David Letterman show in 1995, Dick Assman, and he is something of a local celebrity. Watch.

utterances.speaker: DAVID LETTERMAN, FORMER LATE NIGHT TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: We were kind of taken by the man's name, Dick Assman. I don't know --

utterances.speaker: LETTERMAN
utterances.utterance: I don't know that I've ever met a guy named Assman. Tonight, if we have a second, we'll just call and spend a minute or two here on the show getting to know Dick Assman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Hello?

utterances.speaker: LETTERMAN
utterances.utterance: Hello, who is this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Dick Assman.

utterances.speaker: LETTERMAN
utterances.utterance: Oh, Dick.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: First of all, I missed that David Letterman. That was before he was all caught up in politics.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: This sparked something called Ass-mania. Now his relative Dave Assman can't get local authorities to allow him to put his family name on his license. They claim, and I quote, "The committee must abide by a set of guidelines regardless of if the word in someone's name is pronounced differently than the offensive version." So because A-s-s-m-a-n appears offensive to people, they will not put it on the license. I am deeply offended for Mr. Assman Oss-man, because what if your name is Boobman, what if you're name is Lipschitz. You can't have a license with your name on it?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Apparently. But you know what I'm offended by? I'm offended by, well, I'm offended by people he do vanity plates at all.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Do you remember this. In "Seinfeld" they had a similar episode about this, in fact with the same Assman reference. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Assman? These don't belong to me. I'm not the Assman. I think there's been a mistake.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: What's your name again?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Cosmo Kramer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Cosmo Kramer. You are the Assman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not the Assman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Well, as far as the state of New York is concerned, you are.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Apparently in Saskatchewan, a real Assman cannot put his name out there. I say be a proud Assman, put your name on your license. He should take it to the high court.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Media-ite.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Raymond --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: -- for that Friday Follies. My God, what's happened to us? After a batch of stolen texts revealed the sultry affair he was having, Amazon and "Washington Post" CEO Jeff Bezos is leveling a charge of extortion against the "National Enquirer." So why is Peter Schweizer calling him a hypocrite? That's next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: A lurid affair caught on text and charges of extortion, and that's the state of play between one of the wealthiest men on the planet and the most famous tabloid in American history. Trace Gallagher has the story tonight from our west coast newsroom that's buzzing. Trace?

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.utterance: Hi, Laura. When the world's richest man says he was blackmailed by the world's most famous tabloid it tends to generate a little buzz, and now you have the feds involved. First Bezos went on a blogging platform called Medium and posted details of the alleged extortion, including messages sent to him from the "National Enquirer," its parent company American Media, and American Media CEO David Pecker, threatening to release intimate photos of Bezos and his girlfriend Lauren Sanchez unless Bezos agreed to, one, call off his investigation of how "The Enquirer" got the private pictures and texts, and, two, issued a statement saying the investigation that uncovered his affair with Sanchez was not politically motivated. Bezos of course refused, writing, quote, "Of course I don't want personal photos published, but I also won't participate in their well-known practice of blackmail, political favors, political attacks, and corruption. I prefer to stand up, roll this log over, and see what crawls out." American Media has now responded, saying it wasn't blackmailing Bezos and that the messages were good faith negotiations to resolve the matter, saying, quote, "American Media believes fervently that it acted lawfully in the reporting of the story of Mr. Bezos." That said, American Media CEO David Pecker says the company will conduct its own investigation into what, if any, action needs to be taken. And the government is also getting in on the action. Federal prosecutors are now looking into the "National Enquirer's" is handling of the Bezos extramarital affair story. As for how the intimate photos were leaked in the first place, a reporter for the "Washington Post" owned by Jeff Bezos says that he has spoken with Bezos' lead security consultant Gavin de Becker. Watch. MANUEL ROIG-FRANZIA, "WASHINGTON POST": Gavin de Becker told us that he does not believe that Jeff Bezos' phone was hacked. He thinks it's possible that a government entity might have gotten hold of his text messages.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.utterance: Though earlier, Gavin de Becker said publicly he thought the brother of Bezos' mistress Lauren Sanchez played a role in leaking those private photos and texts. We shall see. Laura?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Trace, great job. And our next guest finds the invasion of privacy complaints from Bezos warranted, but also hypocritical. Filmmaker Peter Schweizer has a new documentary that examines how these tech behemoths operate in stolen and manipulated information, that is your information, by the way. Peter joins us now. Peter, the "National Enquirer" seems to be in the wrong here with how they came after Bezos, but it's kind of ironic, isn't it, that Bezos is crying foul about stolen text when these tech companies can be guilty in the end of much worse.

utterances.speaker: PETER SCHWEIZER, PRESIDENT, GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY INSTITUTE
utterances.utterance: That is exactly right, Laura. utterances.utterance: It's interesting, Jeff Bezos is in this story kind of the victim, right, so that is going to help him.
